context:
How sad...  was the drone okay?  Did it survive?

The dem terrorists will next start attaching bombs to these drones.

Hernandez? He should be ok.

The guy who remotely controlled the LAPD helicopter didn't see it coming?

How big was this drone that it could take down a helicopter.  

Fake news.  There was a collision, but no danger.  Can a suicidal pelican take out a helicopter?

This happens when laws are disorganized or absent altogether.

Clear concise laws are desperately needed.

200 ft and below drones are legally protected but must leave the area when emergency aircraft responders are present.

Emergency responders should have a means to shut down drone signals within a confined localized area.

I'm sure there's more, better ideas out there but we don't have any and we badly need them federally uniformly applied.
Attempted murder sounds more like it. Fry him!
he will just be let go........the Dems want no prison !

Andrew Rene Hernandez, 22, was arrested by FBI agents Thursday and charged with one count of unsafe operation of an unmanned aircraft. 'Unsafe operation of a unmanned aircraft' This is a weak and lame charge. The officer(s) on this craft could have been seriously injured if not killed. Attempted murder or attempted man slaughter would be a better charge.
California Dreamin'......like all those who died in CA from drug overdose. Liberals should have learned that lesson.

"The misdemeanor offense is punishable by up to a year in prison." Well, thank goodness it's a federal crime and charge where, perhaps, there will be some real or meaningful consequences. California has all but ceased prosecuting misdemeanor offenses, while simultaneously re-classifying many crimes which once were felonies to misdemeanors. Oh, and don't fool yourself into believing for a single moment the criminal element in California is not aware of this change and knows EXACTLY what or how much havoc they can wreak without fear of consequences.
Let him be the prisoner who other drone idiots think of before they go flying near aircraft.
He should quit being so damn nosey!
"Unsafe operation" ? How about "Attempted Murder" of Police ?

Be read to hear this kinda news more often in the future.
We know that members of congress do not have enough brains to foresee this coming.
Green new deal will have clear air travel only for socialists elites.
This kid is toast.

My son is a corporate pilot and has had 3 near-misses around LAX in the past year from idiot drone users.  All of the events were reported to air traffic control and the FAA, but it is hard to nab the perpetrators in real time.  The yahoos with the drones are putting a lot of lives in jeopardy when they fly in restricted airspace.

out on bail getting a great thanksgiving meal. thanks Kyle for doing the right thing!
Domestic terrisom.prison for life.

doing things like killing people.

This reminds me of the solar plane experiment.....a light plane with huge wings and body full of solar panels....and fully charged batteries......couldn't even fly one person.....with strong prevailing winds....from Japan to Hawaii. It's called 'Dreamers Meet Reality'!

"Authorities do not believe Hernandez intentionally caused the drone to ram the copter."  So...it was an accident?  Sort of like if he clipped a police car...accidentally?  Maybe his attorney should trot out the DOJ's "no criminal intent" language used for Hillary.

It is important to prosecute these cases to help prevent disasters.  Those who are licensed to fly drones know the dangers and risks they could pose.  Prosecute every single one.

no different than damaging something with a car.

The dominion voting software company agree to testify before the Pennsylvania House committee yesterday, and then they did not show up! If they are innocent, why would they not testify?

Drones Lives Matter. Throw the book at him.

"unsafe operation of an unmanned aircraft"

This could easily happen if the pilots of both aircraft were operating as safe as possible. Police and news helicopters don't file "flight plans" and don't fly in a linear fashion. They change direction and altitude at will‚Äîso long as they avoid fixed-wing aircraft "lanes".

All aircraft‚Äîincluding drones‚Äîshould be required to have ADS-B transponders. That way they can all be tracked and identified in real time. Simple inexpensive ADS-B based warning systems can be implemented to avoid collisions.

All things considered he was being a good citizen and recording a crime scene. Not really different in principle from recording a crime in progress on your phone. I'm glad nobody was injured and hope the court goes easy on this guy.

What do I think? I think there are a lot of really stupid people who have no common sense at all. Flying a drone near a police helicopter is as stupid as driving you car near a police vehicle in code three.
Ban drones.  They are more dangerous than weapons when in the hands of liberals.

Please forgive me! Any liberal judge would throw out the offense, and close the case for ever.

There are pretty clear and detailed regulations for sUAS (small unmanned aircraft systems - FAA parlance for ‚Äúdrones‚Äù) and people need to get nailed for not following them.  These things aren‚Äôt toys.  They need to be operated responsibly, not like most doofuses out there operate cars and everything else.

This underscores why ill never support having ‚Äúflying cars‚Äù without requiring the operators to hold a pilot certificate - the last thing we need is imbeciles inserting themselves into the National airspace system like they‚Äôve done with our highway and roadway system.  Some competence and ‚Äúskin in the game‚Äù is required.
did the drone hit the helicopter or did the helicopter hit the drone?  The drone could have been just flying around being a good little drone when the police helicopter assaulted it.

Was he checking it out out to see if they could start looting the stores?

Another TERRIBLE article written by Fox News.  The article first says the drone was "crashed into" the helicopter.  That suggests a deliberate action on the part of the operator.  On the other hand, the drone camera was recovered and it had pictures of the operator.  It is doubtful that he intentionally crashed his drone into the helicopter.  In the hurry to bring this to our attention FIRST, we got a story that is more a collection of loose ends than of fact.

I suspect that the drone operator will be found responsible.  And should be.

PERIOD

There is a huge prop rotating at a speed to lift thousands of pounds creating a downdraft that people have a hard time over coming when walking under it, and yet we are to believe a Drone of a pound or two flies right through it...

It would be like a Humming Bird flying over an outside air conditioner condenser....

Shoots straight up...as the Drone would shoot straight down....

FAA places a 400 foot ceiling on remote controlled aircraft.  If the drone was above 400 feet it was the drone pilot's fault.  If below, then the drone pilot did nothing wrong.  But the drone does need to give right-of-way to a manned aircraft - it the drone pilot saw the heli in time.

Many years ago I saw a car on an interstate highway being driven way too fast for the blizzard conditions.  Sure enough, he lost traction on a slight curve and slid right into the corner of a state patrol car on the shoulder.  Nothing serious, but Im sure the officer was not amused.  But a drone hitting a police copter... that's an ah-sheet moment.

Why should this surprise anyone?  As an ex-FAA lawyer, I can tell you that just about anyone could see the potential for mischief and tragedy that these drones are capable of causing.  They have been operated near airports and have almost caused crashes.  These drones in the hands of amateurs are an accident\tragedy waiting to happen.  Sure, most people are responsible but others are not.  Aircraft are most vulnerable during take-off and ascent from the airport and on short final approach to landing.  That is exactly where a drone flying in restricted airspace too near an airport will be.
Probably was intentional.

They need to require licenses for drones and they need to ban flying them in residential neighborhoods. Some moron was flying one in my backyard and looking in windows with it. Tossed a football at it and knocked it out of the air then crushed it up. When he knocked on the door asking for it, I told him you‚Äôre going to have to call the PD. If you involve them I‚Äôm going to pursue peeping tom charges against you...
We enjoy freedom and the liberties that gives us.  Freedom does not absolve anyone from their responsibility while exercising those liberties.

It might not be the criminal charges that the guy regrets most. I assume he will get some kind of unsupervised probation unless there is more to him than this. BUT, the restitution or the civil suit for repairs to the helicopter may last way longer than criminal charges. At a few hundred an hour for an A&P mechanic.... OUCH.

Speaking of the French Latino, I was in the military with a redheaded Mexican.

I think this was a trial run for gangs to test the feasibility of using a drone against a police or other helicopter.  A new terrorist weapon.  Think of it as a cheap guided missile.  You know an airliner is next.  This should be life in prison!

Not that it matters legally, but you wonder if they considered that the helicopter might have run into the hovering drone?

To date -- out of the tens of millions of drone flights conducted globally -- not even ONE fatality or serious injury has ever been attributed to a civilian drone striking a manned aircraft

And if/when it finally does? It will mean the odds of it happening again are one in many, many millions of flights.  Meanwhile, if you live in the US the odds of your being struck by lightning in your lifetime are exponentially higher at 1 in 3,000

Boy, I have seen some pretty stupid and uninformed comments on this thread.  First, drones for some time now are regulated under FAA rule Part 107 and must maintain a certain distance from people, buildings or........other aircraft.  Furthermore, a drone that runs into or is struck by a first responder aircraft to an incident can't sue the LAPD.  For the drone operator it's called see and avoid.  He violated both State and Federal FAA laws.  Most likely he will get a letter of reprimand and a lecture from the LAPD and a FAA Flight Standards inspector.
Biden fly‚Äôs his drone in the basement
It was bound to happen.
Apartment dwellers ruin everything
They‚Äôll want to ban all private ownership of drones just because of a few bad apples.~The liberal way

Hernandez obviously is not informed.  Was his drone FAA registered???  Well known requirement among drone pilots .... except for him, obviously.  I hope enforcement realizes he is the exception ... and not the rule.  Drone flight is (now) heavily regulated and most fly legally and safely.

"Up to a year" is actually pretty lenient for how horrible to accident could have gone...  The drone gets pulled into the rotors taking down the officers incident and potentially bringing a helicopter crash into a populated and crowded part of LA.

Offender would do best to smile, nod, apologize constantly, and take his lumps.

Indicting this drone flyer with one-count of "unsafe operation of an unmanned drone" is a wimpy charge that assures even more severe consequences of reckless drone operation. If a licensed pilot operated an aircraft in manner that collided ever so slightly with a police helocopter and forced it to land he would be in a hell of lot more trouble and likely lose his pilot's license. All drone-operators who fly a drone over 250' in the air should be required to be licensed and carry liability insurance. Some training in FAA flight rules should be required and even perhaps demonstrated drone piloting capability.  Dones capabible of flying higher than 250' should only be sold to licensed drone operators. These drones are more than mere toys as they have the capacity to cause substancial property damage and personal injury and they have the potential to intentionally inflict significant harm.

Was it a DJI mini or a MQ-1 Predator drone? As a life long Helicopter pilot I would support life without parole, IF Mr Hernandez was truly negligent or trying to ram the helicopter. The story fails to provide sufficient details to arrive at a decision.   If the LAPD copter was flying at tree top level at a high rate of speed and hit the drone over Mr Hernandez's property, I'd go with Mr Hernandez. If the drone was above 500 feet over the surface, I go with LAPD. Over the years I've seen a lot of Hueys and OH58's (Jet Ranger) make contact with trees, ground and a bunch of other objects (and animals/birds) and most of the time the aircraft brings it's crew home. During single pilot operation I would be a lot more concerned about an object or bird coming through the windshield that the rotor system.
Charge him with the chopper repairs.

Ban drones - they‚Äôre noisy and an invasion of our privacy

And the government controls the air space. Not to be a smart ask, but why was this chopper in the air? How is it government gets to control air space that is not connected with any airport, flight patterns or secure areas? The fact is, if a drone operator crashes into property on the ground, or in the air, he should simply be responsible for damages. Now the government is saying that they own every piece of air space and that also is not true. This drone operator should have as much right to the air space as the LAPD and if the LAPD would have crashed into the drone, they should be responsible for damages. Who gave the government control over the air space? Did we, the people? Or did they just take it upon themselves to claim all rights over it?
The accused needs to say that he was helping to defund the police.
"The criminal case is believed to be the first in the nation stemming from a drone collision."  "Who" believes that?

Intentional or not, this is going to continue to happen. This guy should be the unfortunate fool who has to be made an example of.  He needs a little time behind bars which might deter other fools from doing the same thing in the future.
up to a year?  should be a least 5

Congress needs to get the FAA to layout air space regulations for homeowners. These things are sophisticated today, can be purchased and flown by anyone, legally or illegally and can violate your safety and every kind of privacy, you think you have in your home.

States need to extend their Castle Laws to include defending from drone trespassing through your property's air space. Homeowners should have the right to destroy unauthorized drones flying below 500 feet through their air space boundaries.

Crashing into helicopters is only the beginning...
The govmint restricting more freedoms. Not surprising at all.
